messages.content: What martial art(s) should I learn to fight really well, I don't care much about sport or exercise or anything, just fighting

If you're looking to learn a martial art to improve your fighting skills, I recommend learning Muay Thai, also known as Thai boxing. Muay Thai is a Thai martial art that focuses on striking and kicking techniques, as well as clinching (grappling) and throws. It is known for its fast footwork, powerful kicks, and intense training methods.

Muay Thai is a full-contact sport, and training for it can be physically demanding. However, it can also be a great workout and can help to improve your stamina, endurance, and strength. Additionally, Muay Thai can help you to develop good balance, coordination, and focus, which are useful in any type of fighting situation.

If you're looking for a more traditional and cultural experience, you might also consider learning Muay Lao, which is the original form of Muay Thai. Muay Lao emphasized the use of the knee, elbow, and shoulder strikes, which can give you a more well-rounded fighting style.

It's important to note that while these martial arts can be very effective in a fight, they should not be used in a reckless or uncontrolled manner. It's also important to have good self-defense skills and to use physical force only as a last resort, as it can have severe consequences for all parties involved.
Should I just focus in that one or are there other arts I should practice

If you want to learn Muay Thai as a fighting art, it's important to focus on it and give it your full attention. Muay Thai is a complex sport that requires a lot of practice and dedication to master. However, if you're also interested in learning other martial arts for different types of fighting, such as grappling or striking, then you might consider incorporating those arts into your training regimen.

For example, if you're interested in learning how to grapple, you could practice Brazilian jiu-jitsu, which is a grappling art that emphasizes submissions, chokes, and holds. If you're interested in learning how to fight with a weapon, you could practice kendo or Western European fencing, which both focus on sword fighting.

Ultimately, the choice of which martial arts to learn will depend on your individual interests, goals, and available time. It's important to choose martial arts that you find interesting and that you're willing to dedicate time and effort to learn.
